awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2022 Fall Workshop on Computational Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports student and postdoctoral fellow attendance at the 2022 Fall Workshop on Computational Geometry (FWCG), to take place during October 14-15, 2022, in Raleigh, NC, at the North Carolina State University. FWCG has a record of strongly encouraging participation by students, for whom the conference serves as a valuable educational experience, both for the technical content of the talks and for the opportunities for networking that it provides. This award will provide partial support to 21 students/postdocs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
The Fall Workshop on Computational Geometry is one of the longest running research symposia held annually in the United States on the topic of computational geometry. It serves an important role in the research community to both disseminate new results prior to the major conferences as well as to provide professional development opportunities to graduates students in the field.

The aim of the workshop was to bring together researchers from academia
and industry, to stimulate collaboration on problems of common interest
arising in all areas of geometric computing. Following the tradition of the previous workshops on Computational Geometry, the format of the workshop was informal, extending over two days, with several breaks scheduled for discussions.  There were 19 accepted talks presented (all but two presented live in person) and two invited talks from experts in the field.  
The funds from this award supported travel for 14 US-based researchers to travel to Raleigh and attend the workshop at North Carolina State University. This is the first time since the pandemic that the conference was held in person. For several of the participants, it was their first time presenting research in person in a conference setting.  The workshop had 63 registered attendees and the intimate, single track setting provided many opportuniteis for engagement and networking.  In this way, the workshop served the important broader impact of furthering the professional development of graduate students and postdocs in the field.

Last Modified: 09/25/2023
Modified by: Donald Sheehy
